Description: Terracotta female figure with hair worn back into a cap or headdress. Possibly from a doll, of a dancer wearing a 'Scythian cap', which would make this a representation of an Amazon(?). Head only. Mould-made and solid. Traces of red paint on hair. Orange fabric with buff surfaces. Common fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Produced in Alexandria, or (less likely) imported. Very crude mould-made Artemis(?). Parallel from Sicily (Higgins, 1954, no.1162, 315) dated to the late 5th century BC. Parallel from Corinth dated late 4th to early 3rd century BC (Merker 2000, 100, nos. C158-160). Merker, G. S. 2000, Corinth : results of excavations conducted by the American School of Classical Studies. Vol. 18, The Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore. Part 4, Terracotta figurines of the Classical, Hellenistic, and Roman periods, American School of Classical Studies at Athens, Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.412) (Phase 1)
